content.question: An administrator at a local high school wants to investigate whether there is an association between the grade level of a student (either ninth, tenth, eleventh, or twelfth) and how the student commutes to school (either walks, bikes, takes the bus, receives a ride, or drives). After a chi-square test for association was conducted, the results indicated that the chi-square test statistic was 14.63 with a <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of 0.2623. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value in the context of the test?

choices.label: There is a 26.23 percent chance that grade level and how a student commutes to school are independent.
There is a 26.23 percent chance that there is no association between grade level and how a student commutes to school.
Assuming there is no association between a student’s grade level and how the student commutes to school, there is a 26.23 percent chance of finding a test statistic that is 14.63 or larger.
Assuming that a student’s grade level and the way the student commutes to school are dependent, there is a 26.23 percent chance of finding a test statistic that is 14.63 or larger.
Assuming that a student’s grade level and the way the student commutes to school are dependent, there is a 26.23 percent chance of finding a test statistic that is 14.63 or smaller.

content.answer: Assuming there is no association between a student’s grade level and how the student commutes to school, there is a 26.23 percent chance of finding a test statistic that is 14.63 or larger.

topic.text: 8.6: Carrying Out a Chi-Square Test for Homogeneity or Independence

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
